86  template<class Scalar, class Ordinal>
87  class Element {
88  public:
96  Element () : rowIndex_ (-1), colIndex_ (-1), value_ (0) {}
97 
99  Element (const Ordinal i, const Ordinal j, const Scalar& Aij) :
100  rowIndex_ (i), colIndex_ (j), value_ (Aij) {}
101 
103  bool operator== (const Element& rhs) {
104  return rowIndex_ == rhs.rowIndex_ && colIndex_ == rhs.colIndex_;
105  }
106 
108  bool operator!= (const Element& rhs) {
109  return ! (*this == rhs);
110  }
111 
113  bool operator< (const Element& rhs) const {
114  if (rowIndex_ < rhs.rowIndex_)
115  return true;
116  else if (rowIndex_ > rhs.rowIndex_)
117  return false;
118  else { // equal
119  return colIndex_ < rhs.colIndex_;
120  }
121  }
122 
128  template<class BinaryFunction>
129  void merge (const Element& rhs, const BinaryFunction& f) {
130  TEUCHOS_TEST_FOR_EXCEPTION(
131  rowIndex() != rhs.rowIndex() || colIndex() != rhs.colIndex(),
132  std::invalid_argument,
133  "Attempt to merge elements at different locations in the sparse "
134  "matrix. The current element is at (" << rowIndex() << ", "
135  << colIndex() << ") and the element you asked me to merge with it "
136  "is at (" << rhs.rowIndex() << ", " << rhs.colIndex() << "). This "
137  "probably indicates a bug in the sparse matrix reader.");
138 
139  value_ = f (rhs.value_, value_);
140  }
141 
148  void merge (const Element& rhs, const bool replace=false) {
149  TEUCHOS_TEST_FOR_EXCEPTION(
150  rowIndex() != rhs.rowIndex() || colIndex() != rhs.colIndex(),
151  std::invalid_argument,
152  "Attempt to merge elements at different locations in the sparse "
153  "matrix. The current element is at (" << rowIndex() << ", "
154  << colIndex() << ") and the element you asked me to merge with it "
155  "is at (" << rhs.rowIndex() << ", " << rhs.colIndex() << "). This "
156  "probably indicates a bug in the sparse matrix reader.");
157 
158  if (replace) {
159  value_ = rhs.value_;
160  }
161  else {
162  value_ += rhs.value_;
163  }
164  }
165 
167  Ordinal rowIndex() const { return rowIndex_; }
168 
170  Ordinal colIndex() const { return colIndex_; }
171 
173  Scalar value() const { return value_; }
174 
175  private:
176  Ordinal rowIndex_, colIndex_;
177  Scalar value_;
178  };
179 
190  template<class Scalar, class Ordinal>
191  std::ostream&
192  operator<< (std::ostream& out, const Element<Scalar, Ordinal>& elt)
193  {
194  typedef ScalarTraits<Scalar> STS;
195  // Non-Ordinal types are floating-point types. In order not to
196  // lose information when we print a floating-point type, we have
197  // to set the number of digits to print. C++ standard behavior
198  // in the default locale seems to be to print only five decimal
199  // digits after the decimal point; this does not suffice for
200  // double precision. We solve the problem of how many digits to
201  // print more generally below. It's a rough solution so please
202  // feel free to audit and revise it.
203  //
204  // FIXME (mfh 01 Feb 2011)
205  // This really calls for the following approach:
206  //
207  // Guy L. Steele and Jon L. White, "How to print floating-point
208  // numbers accurately", 20 Years of the ACM/SIGPLAN Conference
209  // on Programming Language Design and Implementation
210  // (1979-1999): A Selection, 2003.
211  if (! STS::isOrdinal) {
212  // std::scientific, std::fixed, and default are the three
213  // output states for floating-point numbers. A reasonable
214  // user-defined floating-point type should respect these
215  // flags; hopefully it does.
216  out << std::scientific;
217 
218  // Decimal output is standard for Matrix Market format.
219  out << std::setbase (10);
220 
221  // Compute the number of decimal digits required for expressing
222  // a Scalar, by comparing with IEEE 754 double precision (16
223  // decimal digits, 53 binary digits). This would be easier if
224  // Teuchos exposed std::numeric_limits<T>::digits10, alas.
225  const double numDigitsAsDouble =
226  16 * ((double) STS::t() / (double) ScalarTraits<double>::t());
227  // Adding 0.5 and truncating is a portable "floor".
228  const int numDigits = static_cast<int> (numDigitsAsDouble + 0.5);
229 
230  // Precision to which a Scalar should be written. Add one
231  // for good measure, since 17 is necessary for IEEE 754
232  // doubles.
233  out << std::setprecision (numDigits + 1);
234  }
235  out << elt.rowIndex () << " " << elt.colIndex () << " ";
236  if (STS::isComplex) {
237  out << STS::real (elt.value ()) << " " << STS::imag (elt.value ());
238  }
239  else {
240  out << elt.value ();
241  }
242  return out;
243  }
244 
281  template<class Scalar, class Ordinal>
282  class Adder {
283  public:
284  typedef Ordinal index_type;
285  typedef Scalar value_type;
286  typedef Element<Scalar, Ordinal> element_type;
287  typedef typename std::vector<element_type>::size_type size_type;
288 
299  Adder () :
300  expectedNumRows_(0),
301  expectedNumCols_(0),
302  expectedNumEntries_(0),
303  seenNumRows_(0),
304  seenNumCols_(0),
305  seenNumEntries_(0),
306  tolerant_ (true),
307  debug_ (false)
308  {}
309 
327  Adder (const Ordinal expectedNumRows,
328  const Ordinal expectedNumCols,
329  const Ordinal expectedNumEntries,
330  const bool tolerant=false,
331  const bool debug=false) :
332  expectedNumRows_(expectedNumRows),
333  expectedNumCols_(expectedNumCols),
334  expectedNumEntries_(expectedNumEntries),
335  seenNumRows_(0),
336  seenNumCols_(0),
337  seenNumEntries_(0),
338  tolerant_ (tolerant),
339  debug_ (debug)
340  {}
341 
362  void
363  operator() (const Ordinal i,
364  const Ordinal j,
365  const Scalar& Aij,
366  const bool countAgainstTotal=true)
367  {
368  if (! tolerant_) {
369  const bool indexPairOutOfRange = i < 1 || j < 1 ||
370  i > expectedNumRows_ || j > expectedNumCols_;
371 
372  TEUCHOS_TEST_FOR_EXCEPTION(indexPairOutOfRange,
373  std::invalid_argument, "Matrix is " << expectedNumRows_ << " x "
374  << expectedNumCols_ << ", so entry A(" << i << "," << j << ") = "
375  << Aij << " is out of range.");
376  if (countAgainstTotal) {
377  TEUCHOS_TEST_FOR_EXCEPTION(seenNumEntries_ >= expectedNumEntries_,
378  std::invalid_argument, "Cannot add entry A(" << i << "," << j
379  << ") = " << Aij << " to matrix; already have expected number "
380  "of entries " << expectedNumEntries_ << ".");
381  }
382  }
383  // i and j are 1-based indices, but we store them as 0-based.
384  elts_.push_back (element_type (i-1, j-1, Aij));
385 
386  // Keep track of the rightmost column containing a matrix
387  // entry, and the bottommost row containing a matrix entry.
388  // This gives us a lower bound for the dimensions of the
389  // matrix, and a check for the reported dimensions of the
390  // matrix in the Matrix Market file.
391  seenNumRows_ = std::max (seenNumRows_, i);
392  seenNumCols_ = std::max (seenNumCols_, j);
393  if (countAgainstTotal) {
394  ++seenNumEntries_;
395  }
396  }
397 
407  void
408  print (std::ostream& out, const bool doMerge, const bool replace=false)
409  {
410  if (doMerge) {
411  merge (replace);
412  } else {
413  std::sort (elts_.begin(), elts_.end());
414  }
415  // Print out the results, delimited by newlines.
416  typedef std::ostream_iterator<element_type> iter_type;
417  std::copy (elts_.begin(), elts_.end(), iter_type (out, "\n"));
418  }
419 
442  std::pair<size_type, size_type>
443  merge (const bool replace=false)
444  {
445  typedef typename std::vector<element_type>::iterator iter_type;
446 
447  // Start with a sorted container. Element objects sort in
448  // lexicographic order of their (row, column) indices, for
449  // easy conversion to CSR format. If you expect that the
450  // elements will usually be sorted in the desired order, you
451  // can check first whether they are already sorted. We have
452  // no such expectation, so we don't even bother to spend the
453  // extra O(# entries) operations to check.
454  std::sort (elts_.begin(), elts_.end());
455 
456  // Walk through the array of elements in place, merging
457  // duplicates and pushing unique elements up to the front of
458  // the array. We can't use std::unique for this because it
459  // doesn't let us merge duplicate elements; it only removes
460  // them from the sequence.
461  size_type numUnique = 0;
462  iter_type cur = elts_.begin();
463  if (cur == elts_.end()) { // No elements to merge
464  return std::make_pair (numUnique, size_type (0));
465  }
466  else {
467  iter_type next = cur;
468  ++next; // There is one unique element
469  ++numUnique;
470  while (next != elts_.end()) {
471  if (*cur == *next) {
472  // Merge in the duplicated element *next
473  cur->merge (*next, replace);
474  } else {
475  // *cur is already a unique element. Move over one to
476  // *make space for the new unique element.
477  ++cur;
478  *cur = *next; // Add the new unique element
479  ++numUnique;
480  }
481  // Look at the "next" not-yet-considered element
482  ++next;
483  }
484  // Remember how many elements we removed before resizing.
485  const size_type numRemoved = elts_.size() - numUnique;
486  elts_.resize (numUnique);
487  return std::make_pair (numUnique, numRemoved);
488  }
489  }
490 
533  void
534  mergeAndConvertToCSR (size_type& numUniqueElts,
535  size_type& numRemovedElts,
536  Teuchos::ArrayRCP<Ordinal>& rowptr,
537  Teuchos::ArrayRCP<Ordinal>& colind,
538  Teuchos::ArrayRCP<Scalar>& values,
539  const bool replace=false)
540  {
541  using Teuchos::arcp;
542  using Teuchos::ArrayRCP;
543 
544  std::pair<size_type, size_type> mergeResult = merge (replace);
545 
546  // At this point, elts_ is already in CSR order.
547  // Now we can allocate and fill the ind and val arrays.
548  ArrayRCP<Ordinal> ind = arcp<Ordinal> (elts_.size ());
549  ArrayRCP<Scalar> val = arcp<Scalar> (elts_.size ());
550 
551  // Number of rows in the matrix.
552  const Ordinal nrows = tolerant_ ? seenNumRows_ : expectedNumRows_;
553  ArrayRCP<Ordinal> ptr = arcp<Ordinal> (nrows + 1);
554 
555  // Copy over the elements, and fill in the ptr array with
556  // offsets. Note that merge() sorted the entries by row
557  // index, so we can assume the row indices are increasing in
558  // the list of entries.
559  Ordinal curRow = 0;
560  Ordinal curInd = 0;
561  typedef typename std::vector<element_type>::const_iterator iter_type;
562  ptr[0] = 0; // ptr always has at least one entry.
563  for (iter_type it = elts_.begin(); it != elts_.end(); ++it) {
564  const Ordinal i = it->rowIndex ();
565  const Ordinal j = it->colIndex ();
566  const Scalar Aij = it->value ();
567 
568  TEUCHOS_TEST_FOR_EXCEPTION(i < curRow, std::logic_error, "The "
569  "current matrix entry's row index " << i << " is less then what "
570  "should be the current row index lower bound " << curRow << ".");
571  for (Ordinal k = curRow+1; k <= i; ++k) {
572  ptr[k] = curInd;
573  }
574  curRow = i;
575 
576  TEUCHOS_TEST_FOR_EXCEPTION(
577  static_cast<size_t> (curInd) >= elts_.size (),
578  std::logic_error, "The current index " << curInd << " into ind "
579  "and val is >= the number of matrix entries " << elts_.size ()
580  << ".");
581  ind[curInd] = j;
582  val[curInd] = Aij;
583  ++curInd;
584  }
585  for (Ordinal k = curRow+1; k <= nrows; ++k) {
586  ptr[k] = curInd;
587  }
588 
589  // Assign to outputs here, to ensure the strong exception
590  // guarantee (assuming that ArrayRCP's operator= doesn't
591  // throw).
592  rowptr = ptr;
593  colind = ind;
594  values = val;
595  numUniqueElts = mergeResult.first;
596  numRemovedElts = mergeResult.second;
597  }
598 
600  const std::vector<element_type>& getEntries() const {
601  return elts_;
602  }
603 
605  void clear() {
606  seenNumRows_ = 0;
607  seenNumCols_ = 0;
608  seenNumEntries_ = 0;
609  elts_.resize (0);
610  }
611 
615  const Ordinal numRows() const { return seenNumRows_; }
616 
620  const Ordinal numCols() const { return seenNumCols_; }
621 
622  private:
623  Ordinal expectedNumRows_, expectedNumCols_, expectedNumEntries_;
624  Ordinal seenNumRows_, seenNumCols_, seenNumEntries_;
625  bool tolerant_;
626  bool debug_;
627 
629  std::vector<element_type> elts_;
630  };
631  } // namespace Raw
632  } // namespace MatrixMarket
633 } // namespace Teuchos
